org.orgName: The District Court of the United States, Western District of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: Bad U.S
In the District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington, Northern Division
Points and Authorities
In the matter of the application of GEORGE KOTROS for a writ of habeas corpus.

The petitioner, George Kotros, is a citizen of Greece; he entered the United States at New York in 1912, immediately came to the State of Washington, and has continuously resided here since that time. On June 21, 1920, he was arrested by virtue of a warrant issued by the Assistant United States Secretary of Labor, which charged:
(a) That he procured or attempted to procure or import a prostitute or person for the purpose of prostitution, or other immoral purpose.
(b) That he entered the United States for an immoral purpose.
(c) That he was a person likely to become a public charge at the time of his entry.
(d) That he entered without inspection.

Thereafter petitioner was given a purported hearing before a United States Inspector at Seattle, Washington; the proceedings were thereupon forwarded to the Secretary of Labor, and on the 15th of December, 1920, an order was made by Louis F. Post, Assistant Secretary of Labor, ordering petitioner deported to Greece. Thereafter petitioner filed an application for a writ of habeas corpus upon which this court issued on order to show cause, and this is the matter now up for hearing.
Petitioner submits the following points and authorities to be urged at the hearing:

The proceedings had before the immigration inspector were unfair and such as to prevent a fair investigation; and that the immigration officers abused their discretion: (Tr. of Proceedings before U.S. Inspr.)
Low Wah v. Backus, 225 U.S. 468 (Cal.; 1912);
Whitfield v. Hanges, 222 Fed. 748-9 (Iowa C.C.; 1915);
Ong Chew Lung v. Burnett, 232 Fed. 853 (Gilbert C.C.1916);
McDonald v. Siu Tak Sam, 225 Fed. 713 (Lewis D.C. 1915)
